news.title: Murakashi Breathes Fire Over Power Outage At Parliament…
news.content:
By Dereck GotoZANU PF Online Activist

Cdes, whichever angle one examines this from, it is utterly indefensible.

How could there possibly be a power outage in Mt. Hampden  at the very moment the Head of State was delivering a nationally broadcast State of the Nation Address  while suburbs across Harare enjoyed uninterrupted electricity throughout?

Was power to Parliament not prioritised, safeguarded, and ring-fenced as a matter of basic protocol? Such negligence is not a mere technical glitch; it reflects a lapse in foresight and coordination at the highest operational level.

This was not only profoundly disrespectful to His Excellency, the President, but it also brought national embarrassment at a time when the entire world was watching.

We simply cannot afford such avoidable blunders during moments of national significance.

Ndatenda.

news.title: Meaningless Figures About ZiG Gaining Strength Despite Worsening Economic Turmoil
news.content:
By A Correspondent

Zimbabwes much-hyped gold-backed currency, the ZiG, is once again being portrayed as a success story on paper  even as ordinary citizens continue to struggle under deepening economic hardship.

According to figures released by the Zimbabwe National Statistics Agency (ZIMSTAT) on Tuesday, annual inflation for October reportedly dropped sharply by 50 percentage points to 32.7%, down from 82.7% in September.

ZIMSTAT stated:The ZiG year-on-year inflation rate (annual percentage change) for the month of October 2025 as measured by the all-items ZiG Consumer Price Index (CPI) was 32.7%. This means that prices, as measured by the all-items ZiG CPI, increased by an average of 32.7% from October 2024 to October 2025.

While the agency presents this as a sign of stability, the reality on the ground paints a different picture  prices of basic goods continue to soar, fuel costs are rising, and the cost of living remains unbearable for most Zimbabweans.

ZIMSTAT also claimed that inflation in US dollar terms had fallen slightly, standing at 13% in October compared to 13.4% in September.The USD year-on-year inflation rate (annual percentage change) for the month of October 2025 as measured by the all-items USD Consumer Price Index (CPI), was 13%. This means that prices as measured by the all-items USD CPI increased by an average of 13% from October 2024 to October 2025.

However, the agency admitted that month-on-month inflation in USD terms had risen to 0.3% in October, up from 0% the previous month.The USD month-on-month food and non-alcoholic beverages inflation rate was 0.2% in October 2025, gaining 0.1 percentage points on the September 2025 rate of 0.1%. The October 2025 USD month-on-month non-food inflation rate was 0.4%, gaining 0.5 percentage points on the September 2025 rate of -0.1%.

For the ZiG, the month-on-month inflation rate reportedly stood at -0.4%, a figure that seems detached from the reality of rising commodity prices in local markets.The ZiG month-on-month food and non-alcoholic beverages inflation rate was 0.7% in October 2025, gaining 0.5 percentage points on the September 2025 rate of 0.2%. The October 2025 ZiG month-on-month non-food inflation rate was -0.9% shedding 0.4 percentage points on the September 2025 rate of -0.5%.
news.description:
By A Correspondent Zimbabwe’s much-hyped gold-backed currency, the ZiG, is once again being portrayed as a success story on paper …

Continue reading "Meaningless Figures About ZiG Gaining Strength Despite Worsening Economic Turmoil"

news.title: Power Was There, Generator Failure Caused SONA Blackout
news.content:
By Engineer Jacob Kudzayi Mutisi | It has emerged that during the Presidents State of the Nation Address (SONA) in Mt. Hampden, national power supply was fully available what failed was the standby generator that the responsible ministry had installed and depended on.

According to sources close to Parliament, electricity from the national grid was not interrupted, instead, the generator meant to provide backup power malfunctioned at the critical moment, plunging the chamber into darkness mid-speech.

Among the engineers, there is now growing sentiment that the Presidents team of intelligence officers (CIO) should include at least one qualified electrical engineer and t communication engineer to verify and certify that all systems especially power and communication are fully operational before any future engagements.

Engineer Jacob Kudzayi Mutisi+263772278161

news.title: Opposition MP Labels Mnangagwa’s SONA “Empty Talk Show”
news.content:
By A Correspondent

HARARE  Honourable Corban Madzivanyika, MP for Mbizo Constituency, has condemned President Emmerson Mnangagwas State of the Nation Address (SONA) delivered on Tuesday, 25 October 2025, describing it as hollow, lifeless, and disconnected from the countrys realities.

Speaking on the address, Madzivanyika said: The State of the Nation Address, as highlighted by President Emmerson Mnangagwa today, to me, is the same old rhetoric. It was hollow and lifeless, to say the very least.

He criticised the Presidents focus on sanctions, saying: It is common knowledge that all EU sanctions were removed. The only sanctions are on Mnangagwa himself due to corruption. Mnangagwa is on sanctions, Mnangagwa is not Zimbabwe, and Zimbabwe is not Mnangagwa. The sanctions propaganda is now tired.

On social welfare programs, the MP noted: He spoke of social safety nets; he talked about Pfumbudza and BEAM, saying we are doing well It is common knowledge that the bulk of Pfumbudza is being stolen by Zanu PF. The supposed beneficiaries are getting only a cup. BEAMgovernment owes 92 billion to BEAM. There is nothing on the ground.

Madzivanyika also questioned infrastructure projects: Construction of silos across the countryhow much do those silos cost? The same silos with the same structure were constructed in Zambia and Mozambique. We cant say we are doing well while stealing from the same countries.

He highlighted the ongoing electricity challenges, saying: We spend the bulk of our time in darkness. He talked about independent power producers they need assurance from government; they need assurance, so we cant expect improvement in the country. Solar accessories are still liable to duty. Make sure solar accessories are duty-free.

The MP also raised concerns over mining and land degradation: He appeared concerned on paper, saying some miners are degrading our land. It is the President himself, and ZIDA, that allowed mining on our sacred land. They gave the miners authority to mine on sacred land. Mnangagwa is shedding tears on the issue.

On governance and debt, Madzivanyika said: The President went on to highlight issues of infrastructure. The President is not sincere. For you to do long-term development, Zimbabwe owes 12 billion to international creditors. Structural dialogue platformsgovernment is not interested. Government is negotiating in bad faith. The governance pillar requires government to ensure that there is a free and fair election. Persistent abuse of human rights, detention of political opponentswe will not get funding.

He further criticised the state of healthcare in the country: The President came to talk about making strides in the health sector. Every Tom, Dick, and Harry can see that there is a serious health crisis. No medication, no vital medicationnot even antibioticsonly a nurse writing a prescription for you. The health system has crumbled beyond reasonable doubt. You will not find ventilators. Go to any rural clinic.

Summarising his view on the SONA, Madzivanyika said: The SONAit was a mere talk show, empty rhetoric, meaningless. So, by and large, the State of the Nation Address did not address anything. Same old rhetoric, purelyit did not inspire confidence, nothing to do with the problems the country is facing.
news.description:
By A Correspondent HARARE – Honourable Corban Madzivanyika, MP for Mbizo Constituency, has condemned President Emmerson Mnangagwa’s State of the …

Continue reading "Opposition MP Labels Mnangagwa’s SONA “Empty Talk Show”"

news.title: Jacob Mudenda Sends Chilling Warning To “Person Who Switched Off Power” During Mnangagwa’s State Of The Nation Address…
news.content:
By A Correspondent

President Emmerson Mnangagwas State of the Nation Address (SONA) was briefly interrupted by a power outage on Tuesday  despite the event being powered by a standby generator.

According to reports, Parliament had requested the Zimbabwe Electricity Supply Authority (ZESA) to serve as the backup power source. The generator was switched on at 12 PM, with ZESA engineers on standby. However, it developed a technical fault around 2:30 PM while President Mnangagwa was still delivering his speech.

A source close to the incident revealed: It appears ZESA engineers restored power, but Local Government engineers took too long to lift the breaker and switch back to ZESA.

Speaker of Parliament Jacob Mudenda, whose office has been linked to the mishap, expressed outrage over the embarrassing incident, vowing that those responsible would face consequences.

The culprits will regret the day of their existence, said Mudenda.

The incident marked the second time Mnangagwa has been humiliated by a power blackout while addressing Parliament, raising questions about the management of critical national events.
news.description:
By A Correspondent President Emmerson Mnangagwa’s State of the Nation Address (SONA) was briefly interrupted by a power outage on …

Continue reading "Jacob Mudenda Sends Chilling Warning To “Person Who Switched Off Power” During Mnangagwa’s State Of The Nation Address…"

news.title: Chibaya In Court For Laundering US$1 Million
news.content:
A local businessman recently appeared in court on allegations of contravening the Exchange Control Act after laundering US$1 158 413.

Sungai Chibaya (38) was granted US$50 bail when he appeared at the Harare Magistrates Court and will be back in court on November 11.

The court heard that during the period between February 14, 2024 and July 24, 2025, and at shop number 12A corner Albion Street and Joseph Msika Street (formerly Cameroon Street), Harare, Chibaya received cash from clients for buying and shipping of goods from Tanzania and Zambia amounting to US$1 158 413 and then unlawfully and intentionally made payments to suppliers of the goods in Tanzania and Zambia or incurred some obligation to make payment outside Zimbabwe without the authority of the Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe.

Herald
news.description:
A local businessman recently appeared in court on allegations of contravening the Exchange Control Act after laundering US$1 158 413. …

Continue reading "Chibaya In Court For Laundering US$1 Million"

news.title: Did General Chiwenga Snub Mnangagwa SONA ?
news.content:
By A Correspondent

Vice President Constantino Chiwenga reportedly snubbed President Emmerson Mnangagwas State of the Nation Address (SONA) on Tuesday, amid reports of a deepening power struggle between the two leaders.

Reliable sources at Parliament confirmed that Chiwenga was absent during the high-profile event, which was dramatically interrupted by a power blackout while Mnangagwa was still delivering his address.

This happened at a time when tensions between the President and his deputy are escalating over Mnangagwas reported bid to extend his term beyond constitutional limits, said one parliamentary source.

The same source claimed the power outage was not a coincidence but a calculated move to send a warning to Mnangagwa. The incident was deliberate and planned. I can tell you Vice President Constantino Chiwenga did not attend the State of the Nation Address. It was a deliberate attempt to embarrass Mnangagwa, the source said.

Another insider alleged that personnel from the Military Intelligence Department (MID) were responsible for cutting the power during the address. We know who switched off power. Heads will roll, wait and see, the source added.

The blackout, which left the chamber in darkness for several minutes, has sparked widespread speculation about internal divisions within the ruling ZANU PF, with some interpreting it as a symbolic show of defiance against Mnangagwas leadership.

The Parliament of Zimbabwe has since issued an apology over the power mishap.
news.description:
By A Correspondent Vice President Constantino Chiwenga reportedly snubbed President Emmerson Mnangagwa’s State of the Nation Address (SONA) on Tuesday, …

Continue reading "Did General Chiwenga Snub Mnangagwa SONA ?"

news.title: Mnangagwa’s State Of The Nation Address Mere Empty Talk Show, Opposition MP Declares
news.content:
Honourable Corban Madzivanyika, MP for Mbizo Constituency, speaks on Emmerson Mnangagwas SONA, Tuesday 25 October 2025:

The State of the Nation Address, as highlighted by President Emmerson Mnangagwa today, to me, is the same old rhetoric. It was hollow and lifeless, to say the very least.

To start with, the President began by mentioning the issue of sanctions, saying the US-imposed sanctions are causing damage. It is common knowledge that all EU sanctions were removed. The only sanctions are on Mnangagwa himself due to corruption. Mnangagwa is on sanctions, Mnangagwa is not Zimbabwe, and Zimbabwe is not Mnangagwa. The sanctions propaganda is now tired. He spoke of social safety nets; he talked about Pfumbudza and BEAM, saying we are doing well

It is common knowledge that we have read that the bulk of Pfumbudza is being stolen by Zanu PF. The supposed beneficiaries are getting only a cup. BEAMgovernment owes 92 billion to BEAM. There is nothing on the ground.

Construction of silos across the countryhow much do those silos cost? The same silos with the same structure were constructed in Zambia and Mozambique. We cant say we are doing well while stealing from the same countries.

Electricitywe spend the bulk of our time in darkness. He talked about independent power producers they need assurance from government; they need assurance, so we cant expect improvement in the country.

Solar accessories are still liable to duty. Make sure solar accessories are duty-free.

He appeared concerned on paper, saying some miners are degrading our land. It is the President himself, and ZIDA, that allowed mining on our sacred land. They gave the miners authority to mine on sacred land. Mnangagwa is shedding tears on the issue.

The President went on to highlight issues of infrastructure. The President is not sincere. For you to do long-term development, Zimbabwe owes 12 billion to international creditors. Structural dialogue platformsgovernment is not interested. Government is negotiating in bad faith.

The governance pillar requires government to ensure that there is a free and fair election. Persistent abuse of human rights, detention of political opponents we will not get funding.

The President came to talk about making strides in the health sector. Every Tom, Dick, and Harry can see that there is a serious health crisis. No medication, no vital medicationnot even antibioticsonly a nurse writing a prescription for you. The health system has crumbled beyond reasonable doubt. You will not find ventilators. Go to any rural clinic.

The SONAit was a mere talk show, empty rhetoric, meaningless.

So, by and large, the State of the Nation Address did not address anything. Same old rhetoric, purelyit did not inspire confidence, nothing to do with the problems the country is facing.

news.title: SONA Parly Blackout – Mnangagwa Ignores Security Threats Advice
news.content:
By A Correspondent-President Emmerson Mnangagwa on Tuesday reportedly ignored security advice to evacuate Parliament during a power outage that plunged the new Mount Hampden building into darkness as he delivered his State of the Nation Address (SONA).

Sources within the Presidential security details told ZimEye that Mnangagwa was urged to leave the building for his safety, fearing a possible security threat.

However, the 83-year-old leader refused and insisted on completing his address, continuing to read his speech by torchlight.

The blackout, which occurred near the end of his speech, caused momentary panic among security personnel and government officials. One of the presidents aides was seen holding a flashlight over Mnangagwas notes as he pressed on, a scene captured on camera and widely shared on social media. Power was restored minutes later.

Speaker of ParliamentJacob Mudendalater apologised to the president, describing the incident as unacceptable and hinting at possible sabotage. We will go beyond what happened and trace the culprits and deal with them accordingly. Those that will be found wanting will regret the day of their existence, Mudenda said.

Government spokespersonNdavaningi Mangwanadownplayed the incident, describing it instead as a moment of presidential resilience. Even a power outage couldnt stop a determined President Mnangagwa from fulfilling his constitutional duty. A single torchlight in the dark Parliament became a powerful symbol of his tenacity, Mangwana posted on X (formerly Twitter).

The embarrassing outage has since triggered disciplinary action within the state power utility. According to government insiders, Energy and Power Development Minister July Moyo has ordered the suspension of Zimbabwe Electricity Transmission and Distribution Company (ZETDC) Managing Director Abel Gurupira, pending investigations.

Although ZESA has been blamed for the blackout, government sources revealed that Parliament had deliberately opted to run the event on a hired generator  bypassing ZESAs supply  to avoid a repeat of previous outages. A letter dated October 21, 2025, signed by Acting Clerk of Parliament Nomasonto Audrey Sunga, confirmed that the generator was meant to serve as the primary power source during the SONA.

However, the plan backfired when the generator failed around 2:30 PM, and engineers were unable to switch back to ZESA power due to the incorrect configuration of the circuit breaker. Power was manually restored after more than five minutes.

While officials publicly insist the blackout was a technical mishap, sources close to ZANU PF say the timing of the incident has fueled renewed speculation about deepening divisions within the ruling party, particularly between President Mnangagwas faction and that of his deputy, Vice President Constantino Chiwenga.

The long-running rivalry between the two men dates back to the 2017 military coup that toppled the lateRobert Mugabe, when Chiwenga, then army commander, played a pivotal role in paving the way for Mnangagwas rise to power. Insiders claim the two had a gentlemans agreement that Mnangagwa would serve two terms before handing over to Chiwenga  a promise Mnangagwa now appears unwilling to honour.

Tensions escalated after ZANU PFs 2025 congress endorsed a proposal to extend Mnangagwas rule to 2030 under the partys controversialAgenda 2030plan, effectively blocking Chiwengas succession hopes. Reports suggest that Chiwengas allies in the military and government have faced transfers, demotions, or unexplained dismissals in recent months, as Mnangagwa consolidates his grip on power.

Against this tense political backdrop, theParliament blackouthas been interpreted by some insiders as a symbolic  if not deliberate  embarrassment to the president, reflecting the fragility of the ruling partys internal unity.

Zimbabwe continues to endure daily power cuts lasting between five and eight hours, blamed on low water levels at Kariba Dam and recurrent breakdowns at thermal stations. The latest Parliament incident has reignited public frustration over governance failures and infrastructure decay, even as officials attempt to portray Mnangagwa as resilient in the face of adversity.

For many observers, the spectacle of an octogenarian president delivering a State of the Nation Address under torchlight in a multimillion-dollar Parliament building stands as a powerful metaphor  one of a nation struggling in the dark, both literally and politically.
news.description:
By A Correspondent-President Emmerson Mnangagwa on Tuesday reportedly ignored security advice to evacuate Parliament during a power outage that plunged …

Continue reading "SONA Parly Blackout – Mnangagwa Ignores Security Threats Advice"

news.title: Telecel On The Verge Of Collapse, Voluntarily Goes Under Corporate Rescue
news.content:
One of the countrys telecommunications firms, Telecel Zimbabwe, has been placed under voluntary corporate rescue.

The decision was made by the companys board of directors last Wednesday and took effect on Monday.

Take note that on the 22nd of October 2025, the Board of Directors of Telecel Zimbabwe (Private) Limited (the Company) passed a resolution to place the Company under voluntary corporate rescue in terms of section 122 of the Insolvency Act [Chapter 6:07] (the Act).

Such resolution was duly filed with the Master of the High Court and the Registrar of Companies and took effect on the 27th of October 2025, reads part of the notice.

The notice further advises that All stakeholders, including but not limited to employees, customers, suppliers, creditors and shareholders, are hereby informed of this development.

The corporate rescue process is designed to rehabilitate the company and does not signify an intention to liquidate.

Stakeholders were also advised that,Further take note that, in terms of Section 126 of the Act, a general moratorium on all legal proceedings against the company, or in relation to any property belonging to the company, is now in effect, unless otherwise provided by the Act.

Corporate rescue also known as business rescue or judicial management forms part of Governments broader strategy to rehabilitate distressed but economically significant companies.

It is governed by the Insolvency Act, which replaced the old Companies Act [Chapter 24:03].

The model has become an increasingly preferred intervention to safeguard key national assets, preserve jobs and sustain productivity across various sectors of the economy.
news.description:
One of the country’s telecommunications firms, Telecel Zimbabwe, has been placed under voluntary corporate rescue. The decision was made by …
